MT @VincentRK I also chair the ECOG myeloma committee...ECOG E4A03 idea came from a patient #mmsm

Ok, as others check in (or lurk), let's start T1 – Is myeloma a disease or a syndrome? #mmsm

#EAOnc E4A03 (RD vs Rd) 
http://t.co/Q5iQIaiQrp #mmsm
@CathySoud Great #mmsm
We picked the racial disparities topic to coincide with a paper that @DrOlaLandgren and I published in Leukemia #mmsm
You would need to define disease and syndrome for me #mmsm
RT @VincentRK We picked the racial disparities topic to coincide with a paper that @DrOlaLandgren and I published in Leukemia #mmsm

T1 – Is myeloma a disease or a syndrome?
#mmsm
What we call myeloma right now is similar to a syndrome. Not a unique disease. It is like the term "lymphoma" #mmsm
T1 MT @VincentRK What we call myeloma right now is similar to a syndrome. Not a unique disease. It is like the term "lymphoma" #mmsm
@VincentRK is that because there are many different presentations of myeloma?  #mmsm
So, @VincentRK - myeloma is a syndrome or similar symptoms of a group of diseases that may be molecularly different... #mmsm
There are multiple distinct cytogenetic types. The most common are trisomies, t11;14, t4;14, t6;14, t14;16, and t14;20 #mmsm
RT @VincentRK There are multiple distinct cytogenetic types. The most common are trisomies, t11;14, t4;14, t6;14, t14;16, and t14;20 #mmsm
@mtmdphd T1: I would suggest that is is a disease that presents as a broad range of syndromes.  So both is the answer! #mmsm

T2 – What is MGUS and why does it matter to Myeloma?
(T1 - Myeloma is a syndrome) #mmsm
Exactly. Each of these cytogenetic subtypes starts the MGUS clone. Additional changes then occur causing MGUS to progress to MM #mmsm
MT @jfclearywisc @mtmdphd T1 I would suggest that is is a disease that presents as a broad range of syndromes.  So both is the answer! #mmsm
@jfclearywisc - Great to have you join! #mmsm

@VincentRK T2 – What is MGUS and why does it matter to Myeloma?
#mmsm
@VincentRK so all myeloma patients started out with MGus? #mmsm
@mtmdphd Lurking here Mike, saw the question and couldn’t avoid an answer! #Mmsm
All the reasons why Mantle cell lymphoma is called a separate disease from CLL is present say between the trisomies & t4;14 form of MM #mmsm
@jfclearywisc feel free to lurk or jump in as you wish. #mmsm
MGUS is important because all cases of MM start of as MGUS #mmsm
Critical point -> RT @VincentRK MGUS is important because all cases of MM start of as MGUS #mmsm
MGUS is asymptomatic and is present in about 4% of the general population over the age of 50 #mmsm
@VincentRK but some MGUS never become Myeloma?  #mmsm

MGUS = Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance
#mmsm
Most MGUS does not progress to MM #mmsm
In fact of all MGUS patients diagnosed only 10% will ever develop myeloma #mmsm
RT @VincentRK In fact of all MGUS patients diagnosed only 10% will ever develop myeloma #mmsm
That is why we do not recommend screening for MGUS or treatment #mmsm
@VincentRK do we know why some do and some don't?  #mmsm
@mtmdphd @VincentRK But many people may never know they have/had a MGUS if they present with advanced myeloma #mmsm
We don't know why some progress and some don't. But the probability of progression is like a lottery #mmsm
RT @mtmdphd: RT @VincentRK In fact of all MGUS patients diagnosed only 10% will ever develop myeloma #mmsm
RT @VincentRK We don't know why some progress and some don't. But the probability of progression is like a lottery #mmsm
it is a fixed progression rate. So it is like a second hit has to happen. And the second hit occurs by a random chance event #mmsm
